title: Riot needs to take a stance on animation cancelling- it's counterproductive to their message
body:
For a while now, Riot has been talking about clarity and windows of opportunity to trade in-lane. This clarity ranges from circles in abilities/items, like Ornn's E/Redemption, to rectangles and other markers such as Kayn's W and Ivern's Daisy knock-up. Additionally, Riot has been known to ADD clarity to a champions kit, such as after Zed came out and the X was added so players would know who he was ulting. 

So it baffles me when animation cancelling still exists on a number of champions considering it goes against the Riot mantra. The biggest offender is naturally Riven, though others like Renekton definitely abuse this too. 

The new Janna PBE changes explicitly mention how the CD on her shield is changing to allow better opportunities to trade in lane. Trading in lane being the important part- how can we effectively trade with a Riven in lane if we're not sure what spells she still even has up? In the same thought, how are we supposed to know which spells are up if we can't see them being cast, since they're being cancelled?

Furthermore, Riven is considered a Skirmisher by Riot's own definition- "...Skirmishers aim to shred through any nearby enemy that approaches. Because Skirmishers lack high-end burst damage or reliable ways of closing in on high-priority targets, they are instead armed with situationally powerful defensive tools to survive in the fray, along with extreme sustained damage to cut down even the most durable targets." Animation cancelling allows Riven to not only have reliable options of closing in, since she's moving so fast, but it allows her high-end burst damage. This definition likens Riven more to an Assassin or a Diver than a Skirmisher. 

Either way, it's clear that animation cancelling is a point of contention- look at Nidalee and Graves. Both had their animation cancels taken away. 

Tl;dr- Riot needs to take a stance on animation cancelling for clarity and to allow better trading in lane. Should it be allowed, it needs to be brought back to champions that previously had it.

# Animationcancleing is just overrideing the BACKSWING of an animation with another command, AND NOTHING ELSE!!!

And for AAs, it also has no impact on AS, what it does is allowing you to use the extra time for repositioning or useing skills in between AAs.

What you and most others complain about in the case of riven(and nida) are AA-resets, which let you 'cheat' your AS.
For example if you have a 1.5 AS, the time in between AA-resolves is always 0.75sec, wether you cancle animations or not. However, some skills either soft or hard reset that timer. The most common example of that are empowered AAs loke Jax W or Nasus Q, which imidiatly grant acces to another AA. 
An example for a soft-rest is ashe's Q, it used to fully reset your AA on activation, now it's a partial reset that puts the timer to 40% (so with our 1.5AS, it goes to 0.75 x 0.4 = 0.3sec, so the next AA comes 0.3 sec after useing her Q)

Now what many people didin't know is that Nida had lot's of AA resets in her kit(the cat-W and boith for switches) that alowed her to clear insanely fast aswell as trade rather absurd early on if played perfectly well, and that's what was taken from her, not animation cancleing.

It's also what causes riven to have the fast burst pattern. Each of her Qs is an AA-reset(though not sure if full or partial right now), which is why riven can get the fast combo of. With out the resets, she could chain the Qs fast, but not get in AA's in between, which are actually the main source of damage for her thx to her passive.
On the other hand, without animation-cancleing, riven could hardly use the AA-resets as her Q animation lasts so long that her atackrate hardly changes, which causes the somewhat false impression that animationcancleing is what causes her to Attack faster.

Tl;dr - Animationcancleing is and always was part of **every single champion** and never was removed from anyone. What you mostly complain about are AA-resets, which are a different mechanic.

Regardless of whether one approves of animation canceling or not, I think we can all agree that animation canceling right now is not being treated consistently across all champions. Some champions like Illaoi, Kayn, Kha'Zix and Rengar are specifically given animation locks to prevent them from chaining abilities too quickly, while others, like Riven or most marksmen, are not only allowed to cancel their animations, but are specifically balanced around them doing so. This isn't really a question of fluidity, as Rengo and Kha are both assassins, and should therefore be very fluid, so it's more just an issue of certain champions being given animation cancels just because they feel good, or because players have gotten used to them, while others have those same cancels removed or denied for counterplay reasons, even if one side of the argument could easily be applied to the other. As such, Riot needs to take an official stance on animation cancels, and _even if they do decide to let only certain champions cancel their animations_, they need to give us a definitive enough reasoning on the matter that we can clearly evaluate the consistency of its application.

Personally, I am completely against animation canceling, as I think it's a form of what I'd call empty difficulty in League. Just like empty calories in food contain energy, but no actual nutrition, empty difficulty in League would be mechanics that pose a challenge to the player, but do so without adding any real interaction or gameplay with them and other players, be they teammates or opponents. In this particular case, animation canceling is empty difficulty because it only relies on the player's own ability to identify the point at which an animation can be canceled, and successfully cancel it, and can be achieved literally just by playing a lot of Practice Mode. In fact, many Riven tutorials instruct the player to practice animation canceling and wall-hopping in Practice Mode (or, if the tutorial is a little older, a one-player custom game), and so push the player to master much of a champion's difficulty curve without at all interacting with others. This is not a healthy way of learning to play a PvP game, and for a time was a core reason why Riot didn't want to release Practice Mode in the first place. In a game that already has a very high skill floor relative to most others, additional, extraneous difficulty is not something League really needs, and when it gets particularly severe (as is the case for Riven) it creates really big disconnects in quality of play across mastery, which itself leads to balancing difficulties.
